column4: Opening and Closing Webcam/Video in OpenCV-Python
column5:
The snippet provided does very little work but helpful:
with this codes you can:
. Capture the video via default camera or video on your local machine
. Display every single frame from the captured video
. The program quits when the user presses letter "q" on the keyboard

While getting through the codes, you'll find it easier to understand since every single step has been explained in the comments.
column9:
import cv2
cap = cv2.VideoCapture(0) # Capturing the video via default camera
while cap.isOpened() : # Loop to display every single frame from the captured video
    ret, frame = cap.read()
    cv2.imshow("Motion Detection Camera System", frame)
    if cv2.waitKey(1) & 0xFF == ord('q'): #The program quits when the user presses "q"
        break
cv2.destroyAllWindows() # CLoses all the opened windows
cap.release() # Releases the video

column4: Finding and drawing contours around the moving object
column5:
This is a function that requires two frames from the captured video.
.The two frames are being compared to find the difference between them (changes in frame 2 that are not in frame 1)

. The difference frame is then being changed to gray color for the machine to be able to recognize the features(such as pixels) easily.

. The gray frame is then being blurred to reduce the noise from the image.

. After that, I compared the image pixels with the threshold

. The output was dilated  ( the size of white region/foreground was increased)

. The dilated image was lastly used to find and draw contours on the first frame and printed out to show the moving parts.
column9:
def DrawContours(frame1, frame2):
    while cap.isOpened() :
        # Loop to draw find and draw contours around every moving object
        diff = cv2.absdiff(frame1,frame2)
        gray = cv2.cvtColor(diff, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)
        blur = cv2.GaussianBlur(gray, (5,5), 0)
        _, thresh = cv2.threshold(blur, 20, 255, cv2.THRESH_BINARY)
        dilated = cv2.dilate(thresh, None, iterations=3)
        contours, _ = cv2.findContours(dilated, cv2.RETR_TREE, cv2.CHAIN_APPROX_SIMPLE)
        cv2.drawContours(frame1, contours, -1, (0,255,0), 2) 
        cv2.imshow("Motion Detection Camera System", frame1)
        frame1 = frame2
        ret, frame2 = cap.read()
        if cv2.waitKey(1) & 0xFF == ord('q'): #The program quits when the user presses "q"
            break

column4: Draw rectangles around the moving object in the video
column5:
Here is a snippet of the function that will help you to draw green rectangles around the moving object in the video depending on the area of the moving object.

This function requires 4 parameters.
parameter 1 : The first frame
parameter 2 : The second frame to be compared with the first frame
parameter 3 : The video, it may be your own video from your machine or a video directly from the webcam.
parameter 4 : The area of a moving object you would like to detect.

The algorithm is just the same as the previous snippet about drawing contours around every single moving object,
except that we are now drawing large rectangles around large moving object.

You can exit the function by pressing "q" on your keyboard.
column9:
def drawRectangles(frame1, frame2, video, area):
    while video.isOpened() : # Loop to draw rectangles on large moving object
       diff = cv2.absdiff(frame1,frame2)
       gray = cv2.cvtColor(diff, cv2.COLOR_BGR2GRAY)
       blur = cv2.GaussianBlur(gray, (5,5), 0) # to make the image pixels black and white
       _, thresh = cv2.threshold(blur, 20, 255, cv2.THRESH_BINARY) # is pixel intensity is greater than set threshold, value set is set to 255 else 0
       dilated = cv2.dilate(thresh, None, iterations=3) #Increases the size of the foreground/white region
       contours, _ = cv2.findContours(dilated, cv2.RETR_TREE, cv2.CHAIN_APPROX_SIMPLE)

       for contour in contours:
           (x, y, w, h) = cv2.boundingRect(contour)
        
           if cv2.contourArea(contour) < area:
               continue
           cv2.rectangle(frame1, (x,y), (x+w, y+h), (0, 255, 0), 2)
           cv2.putText(frame1, "Status: {}".format("Movement"), (10, 20), cv2.FONT_HERSHEY_SIMPLEX, 1, (0, 0, 255), 3)

       cv2.imshow("Motion Detection Camera System", frame1)
       frame1 = frame2
       ret, frame2 = video.read()
       if cv2.waitKey(1) & 0xFF == ord('q'): #The program quits when the user presses "q"
           break

-Add reference to "roles" table on User schema 
-Remove "any" keyword on exporting the User Schema. 
-Rename also "users" to "user" to keep the good practice of Mongoose that a model name must be in singular because be default Mongoose will add "s" for you.
column9:
const dates = new Date()

const userSchema = new mongoose.Schema({
  name: String,
  user_id: { type: String, default: uuidv4() },
  company_id: { type: String, default: dates.getTime() },
  company: Object,
  company_slug: Object,
  role: { type: Number, default: 1, ref: "Roles" },
  password: String,
  username: String,
  account: Object,
  seller_id: String,
  email: String,
  registered: { type: Date, default: Date.now },
  type: String,
  profile: {
    imageAddress: String,
    info: Object
  }
})

const User = mongoose.model("user", userSchema)

import mysql.connector
from mysql.connector import Error

try:
    connection = mysql.connector.connect(host='localhost',
                                         database='MDCS',
                                         user='rot',
                                         password='mdcs@#29')
    if connection.is_connected():
        db_Info = connection.get_server_info()
        print("Connected to MySQL Server version: " db_Info)
        cursor = connection.cursor()
        cursor.execute("select database();")
        record = cursor.fetchone()
        print("You're connected to database: " record)

except Error as e:
    print("Error while connecting to MySQL", e)
finally:
    if connection.is_connected():
        cursor.close()
        connection.close()
        print("MySQL connection is closed")

import mysql.connector

try:
    connection = mysql.connector.connect(host='localhost',
                                         database='MDCS',
                                         user='root',
                                         password='MDCS@#29')

    mySql_Create_Table_Query = """CREATE TABLE cameras ( 
                             Id int(11) NOT NULL,
                             Name varchar(250) NOT NULL,
                             Location varchar(250) NOT NULL,
                             registration_date Date NOT NULL,
                             PRIMARY KEY (Id)) """

    cursor = connection.cursor()
    result = cursor.execute(mySql_Create_Table_Query)
    print("cameras table is created successfully ")

except mysql.connector.Error as error:
    print("Failed to create table in MySQL: {}".format(error))
finally:
    if connection.is_connected():
        cursor.close()
        connection.close()
        print("MySQL connection is closed")

column4: Connecting and Inserting data to database using python
column5:
The snippets below are made of 3 files.
file one is called config.ini: contains credentials of the database
file two is called dbconnector.py: it uses config.ini to connect to the database and returns the database credentials 
file three is called: connect.py: it connects to the database using dbconnector.py
column9:
FILE 1: config.ini

[mysql]
host = localhost
database = MDCS
user = root
password = dkfj234@2





FILE 2: dbconnector.py

from configparser import ConfigParser


def read_db_config(filename='config.ini', section='mysql'):
    """ Read database configuration file and return a dictionary object
    :param filename: name of the configuration file
    :param section: section of database configuration
    :return: a dictionary of database parameters
    """
    # create parser and read ini configuration file
    parser = ConfigParser()
    parser.read(filename)

    # get section, default to mysql
    db = {}
    if parser.has_section(section):
        items = parser.items(section)
        for item in items:
            db[item[0]] = item[1]
    else:
        raise Exception('{0} not found in the {1} file'.format(section, filename))

    return db




FILE 3: connect.py

from mysql.connector import MySQLConnection, Error
from dbconnector import read_db_config


def connect():
    """ Connect to MySQL database """

    db_config = read_db_config()
    conn = None
    try:
        print('Connecting to MySQL database...')
        conn = MySQLConnection(**db_config)

        if conn.is_connected():
            print('Connection established.')
        else:
            print('Connection failed.')

    except Error as error:
        print(error)

    finally:
        if conn is not None and conn.is_connected():
            conn.close()
            print('Connection closed.')


if __name__ == '__main__':
    connect()
